Among these we may single out his pleasantly autobiographic one to his friend David Wedderburn (No. XXIX.) ; those to Bishop Patr1ck Forbes, of Corse, and Dr. Robert Baron, both in a strain of condolence (XXVII. and XLIV.); those to John Scot‚ of Scotstarvet (XXX. and XXXI.)‚ and another to William Alexander, Earl of Stirling ; all indicating a pleasant relation of friendly and literary fellowship as subsisting in the circle of which Johnston was, as it were, the centre.
